title: Introduction to the user Interface Architecture

slides.title: The User Interface Architecture
slides.ocrText: The User Interface Architecture

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

Describe the user interface architecture for
Guidewire applications

Describe the kinds of PCF files

Open and edit PCF files

Deploy PCF files

slides.title: Guidewire application UI framework
slides.originalNotes:
Guidewire application UI framework
A PCF is an XSD-validated XML document containing elements that describe the structure, layout, and behavior of the web user interface. The majority of this content is defined at the application level, though some is defined at the platform level.

A widget is a PCF element that will be converted into HTML and displayed. This does not mean that a widget itself will always be visible. Some of the widgets are containers that are only used to group other widgets in a specific layout format. Widgets can specify permissions that the logged in user needs to view/edit the data.

A location is a PCF element that a user (or the application itself) can navigate to. It is used to define how users move from one area of the user interface to the next. A location usually specifies:

1) which part of the browser window will be updated if the application/user navigates to the location
2) what are the permissions that the logged in user needs to viewledit the data in that Location

Note: Both Widget and Location are conceptual representations in this diagram. There are no <Widget /> or <Location elements.

slides.title: Atomic widgets
slides.originalNotes:
Atomic widgets
Atomic widgets are individual field items such as inputs, cells, or buttons. They will always be defined within a container widget or location.

Note: Both Widget and Location are conceptual representations in this diagram. There are no <Widget /> or <Location elements. Atomic Widget is also conceptual representation. There is no <Atomic Widget element.

slides.title: Container widgets
slides.originalNotes:
Container widgets
Container widgets hold other widgets. Each one can be defined either in its own file or as a child container within some other PCF element file.

Note: Both Widget and Location are conceptual representations in this diagram. There are no <Widget /> or <Location elements. Similarly, both Atomic Widget and Container Widget are conceptual representations. There are no <Atomic Widget or <Container Widget /> elements.

The PCF object model is container-based. Each IJI element is modeled as an object, which may contain other objects. The hierarchical structure simplifies the task of locating and modifying visual elements. Furthermore, each element can be declared as an independent and therefore reusable element.

slides.title: Detail View Panels
slides.originalNotes:
Detail View Panels
Detail view panels are generally designed to use widgets to organize and manage a collection of related pieces of information that constitute a single record. The most obvious example is the set of individual fields of an instance of an entity such as User, Claim, or Policy. There are no constraints imposed by the system as to what information can be displayed by a detail view, however; the view could present information from multiple entities that do not even have to be related to one another, in addition to information that does not derive from an entity at all (such as calculated or static values).

The purpose of a detail view panel, however, and the recommended practice behind their use, is to present the user with all of the detailed information that is relevant to that interface, and no information that is irrelevant. In general, this means displaying information about the fields of a particular entity andpossibly fields from a small number of closely related entities.

Detail view panels must contain at least one column and can contain as many columns as necessary to present the widgets in the most effective way for the
slides.notes:

slides.title: J List View Panels
slides.originalNotes:
List View Panels
Just as a detail view panel is designed to allow the user to view detailed information about a single record, a list view panel is designed to allow the user to view summary information about a collection of records.
slides.notes:
List View Panels
Just as a detail view panel is designed to allow the user to view detailed information about a single record, a list view panel is designed to allow the user to view summary information about a collection of records.

slides.title: Review: Container widget hierarchy
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Container widget hierarchy
The arrow indicates that A can contain B. For example, a List View Panel can contain Atomic Widgets but cannot contain a Detail View Panel.

Container widgets can be classified in four categories:

1. The lowest level is comprised of atomic widgets-

2. Atomic widgets can be directly contained only by primary views (detail view panels and list view panels). The purpose of a primary view is to organize atomic widgets into logical groups.

3. Secondary views (card view panels and list detail panels) organize primary views. Secondary views cannot directly contain most atomic widgets-

4. Screens are the top-level containers. Screens are used to connect what is displayed in the user interface with how users navigate through the user interface. A screen can directly contain both primary views and secondary views, but it cannot directly contain most atomic widgets.

5. There is one exceptional case, when a primary view can be placed into another primary view This will be discussed later in the List Views lesson.

6.A secondary view could contain other secondary views.
Input sets do not readily fall into any of these categories. Input sets fit some of the attributes of primary views. They can contain atomic widgets and organize them into logical groups. Input sets cannot be referenced directly by secondary views or screens. Input set must be embedded into detail view panels and cannot have toolbars directly associated with them.
slides.notes:

slides.title: PCF hierarchy review
slides.originalNotes:
PCF hierarchy review
At the top level, PCF elements are split between widgets and locations. This lesson only addresses the high-level classifications of widgets (both atomic and container) and locations. Discussions of specific widgets and locations will follow in future lessons.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
Define the broad purpose for each element category:
•
A) Atomic widgets
B) Container widgets
C)
Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

questionData.question:
Define the broad purpose for each element category:
A) Atomic widgets
B) Container widgets
C) Locations
questionData.answer:
The correct responses are:
A) Atomic widgets display individual elements of data and/or functionality.
B) Container widgets group atomic widgets into logical groups.
C) Locations define how users move from one place in the application to the next.

questionData.answer: A PCF file defines a container widget or location and its contents.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
_- — What does each PCF editor convention mean?
•
A) Acontainer widget shaded light blue
B) Alight green line
C) Ared background
Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

questionData.question:
What does each PCF editor convention mean?
A) A container widget shaded light blue
B) A light green line
C) A red background
questionData.answer:
The correct responses are:
A) The container widget is referenced by the current PCF file and its contents are
contained in another file
B) For the currently selected widget tool, a new widget of that type will be placed in
the current location.
C) The PCF file has an error in it.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer a
What does each PCF editor convention mean?
•
oY” A) Acontainer widget shaded light blue
B) Alight green line
C) Ared background
The correct responses are:
A) The container widget is referenced by the current PCF file and Its contents are
contained in another file
B) For the currently selected widget tool, a new widget of that type will be placed in
the current location.
C) The PCF file has an error in it.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
_- — How do you deploy PCF changes?
•
•
•
Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

questionData.question: How do you deploy PCF changes?
questionData.answer:
You can restart the server. Restarting the server reloads PCF files at startup. A more
efficient approach for development is to Reload the PCF files. With internal tools
enabled, you can use the ALT+SHIFT+L keystroke to reload the PCF files. You can
also log in with an administrator user account and reload PCF files from the Internal
Tools Reload page.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer a
_- — How do you deploy PCF changes?
•
oY” You can restart the server. Restarting the server reloads PCF files at startup. A more
efficient approach for development is to Reload the PCF files. With internal tools
enabled, you can use the ALT+SHIFT+L keystroke to reload the PCF files. You can
also log in with an administrator user account and reload PCF files from the Internal
Tools Reload page.
SOOO ODDDSDoOODDODOoOoS
